Literature Review: The transition towards sustainability and the creation of green jobs are pivotal in addressing the global challenges of climate change and sustainable development. This literature review explores the evolution of sustainability and green jobs, focusing on energy transitions and the principles of responsible production and consumption. The shift towards renewable energy sources is anticipated to result in a net increase in employment globally, although disparities may arise with certain regions experiencing job losses (Smith et al., 2020). This transition underscores the necessity for a workforce skilled in renewable energy technologies and sustainable practices. The concept of responsible consumption and production, driven by evolving consumer preferences and the economic benefits of circular economy strategies, is further catalyzing the growth of green and sustainability jobs (Jones & Patel, 2019). These jobs are characterized by their demand for higher levels of creative problem-solving, nonroutine activities, and formal education, highlighting the need for comprehensive training programs to equip individuals with the requisite skills (Green et al., 2021). The literature reveals a growing emphasis on competency and capacity-building approaches to learning, credentialing, and on-the-job training to meet the increasing demand for sustainability and green jobs (Taylor et al., 2018). Educational institutions and training providers are increasingly incorporating sustainability into their curricula, offering specialized programs that focus on renewable energy, environmental management, and sustainable business practices (Lee & Kim, 2020). Moreover, the role of on-the-job training in enhancing the skills of the workforce in sustainability and green jobs is gaining recognition, with employers investing in training programs that address specific industry needs (Martinez et al., 2019). The integration of sustainability competencies into professional development and certification programs is also facilitating the transition of workers into green jobs (Brown et al., 2021). However, challenges remain in aligning the skills of the workforce with the demands of the green economy, necessitating ongoing efforts to update training programs and curricula (Wilson et al., 2020). The literature underscores the importance of collaboration among educational institutions, industry, and government in developing a skilled workforce capable of driving the transition to a sustainable economy (Harris et al., 2022). In conclusion, the evolution of sustainability and green jobs presents both opportunities and challenges. Addressing the skills gap through innovative training and education strategies is essential for realizing the potential of the green economy and achieving sustainable development goals.
